title: 112_s1957
content: The "Taxpayers Right to Know Act" requires an annual report on the cost, performance, and areas for improvements for government programs. Each fiscal year, agencies must identify and describe all programs, determine administrative expenses and service expenditures, estimate the number of clients and beneficiaries served, and estimate the number of employees administering each program. The head of an agency must identify programs with duplicative missions and overlapping services within the Federal Government. This information can be sourced from the catalog of domestic and international assistance programs. The head of each agency must publish a report on the official website containing information on program performance reviews, improper payment rates, and estimated amounts of improper payments for each program that makes payments. The report must include information on improper payments, unspent program funds, and recommendations to consolidate, eliminate waste, and terminate unnecessary programs. Administrative expenses include costs incurred by agencies, grantees, subgrantees, and other recipients of funds, as well as expenses related to personnel salaries, benefits, property management, travel, program management, promotion, reviews, audits, case management, and communication for programs and activities. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of terms related to programs and services administered by the agency, including services, agency, and performance indicators. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to programs and services administered by agencies, including indicators, performance goals, output measures, and program activities as defined in title 31, United States Code. The term "program" is defined by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget as any organized set of activities directed towards a common purpose or goal undertaken by an agency. AMENDMENTS TO CATALOG OF FEDERAL DOMESTIC ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. The addition of International Assistance Programs to Section 6101 of title 31, United States Code, includes assistance to foreign nations, international organizations, programs administered outside the US, and services funded by agencies in foreign nations or by non-governmental organizations. The term 'assistance program' includes domestic and international assistance programs. Amendments to Section 6102 of title 31, United States Code, remove references to 'domestic' in certain subsections. Section 6104 is amended to include 'international assistance' in subsections (a) and (b). Section 6104(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include additional information required in the catalog, such as the budget function applicable to each assistance program. The catalog of Federal domestic and international assistance programs must include electronic links to annual reports, authorization and appropriation amounts, and compliance with catalog requirements. The Administrator must provide contact information for agency personnel responsible for data quality and compliance, as well as compile an annual report on domestic and international assistance programs. Bulk downloads of catalog data will be available regularly, and there will be a revision to the agency definition. The Administrator will provide contact information for data quality and compliance, compile an annual report on assistance programs, and offer bulk downloads of catalog data. The agency definition will be revised to include offices in the legislative branch. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will prescribe regulations within 120 days of the Act's enactment. Implementation of the Act will begin in the first full fiscal year after enactment.
